title: Dynamics of the Subsets of Natural Numbers: A Nursery Rhyme of Chaos

title_detail.value: Dynamics of the Subsets of Natural Numbers: A Nursery Rhyme of Chaos

summary:
We introduce a metric on the set of all subsets of natural numbers which
converts it into a cantor set.On this set endowed with the metric, we introduce
a very simple map which exhibits chaotic behaviour.This simple map is almost
like a nursery rhyme of chaos.

summary_detail.value:
We introduce a metric on the set of all subsets of natural numbers which
converts it into a cantor set.On this set endowed with the metric, we introduce
a very simple map which exhibits chaotic behaviour.This simple map is almost
like a nursery rhyme of chaos.

author: Mofazzal Azam
fulltext:
DYNAMICS OF THE SUBSETS OF NATURAL NUMBERS: A
NURSERY RHYME OF CHAOS

arXiv:nlin/0108055v1 [nlin.CD] 30 Aug 2001

MOFAZZAL AZAM
THEORETICAL PHYSICS DIVISION, CENTRAL COMPLEX, BHABHA ATOMIC
RESEARCH CENTRE
TROMBAY, BOMBAY-400085 INDIA

Abstract
We introduce a metric on the set of all subsets of natural numbers which
converts it into a cantor set.On this set endowed with the metric, we introduce
a very simple map which exhibits chaotic behaviour.This simple map is almost
like a nursery rhyme of chaos.

1

 The set of all subsets of natural numbers is a much larger set than the set of natural
numbers.In fact, it has the cardinality of the set of real numbers.We shall denote the set of
all subsets of natural numbers by the symbol Σ, set of natural numbers by N, subsets of
natural numbers by α, β etc.
α = (n1 , n2 , ..., nk , ...)
β = (m1 , m2 , ..., mk , ...)

(1)

Here nk and mk are natural numbers and α, β ⊂ N and ∈ Σ.On the set Σ , we define
symmetric set theoretic difference as

k∅k = 0 (2) To the set α = (n1 , n2 , ..., nk ), we associate either

In this paper, we will use the first definition of the norm though we might as well have used
the second one. The distance between two subsets α and β is given by

(5)

It is clear from the definitions that kγk = 0 imply α = β, and the triangle inequality is easily
satisfied. On this set Σ endowed with above mentioned metric, we introduce the "Reduction
by Unity" map Ω, as follows
2

 (n1 , n2 , ..., nk , ..) → (n1 − 1, n2 − 1, ..., nk − 1, ...)
(6)
if none of nk = 1.If one of nk , say n1 = 1, then
(1, n2 , ..., nk , ....) → (n2 − 1, ..., nk − 1, ....)

(7)

It is clear from the definition that the "Reduction by Unity" map Ω is two-to-one.
The above structures defined on the set Σ are very natural. We explain this by the
following physical example.Let us consider an infinite number of boxes.Any number of boxes
can be empty or filled with particles.However, the filled boxes are such that no two boxes
have the same number of particles.The configuration of the particles in the boxes can be
represented by the sequences (n1 , n2 , ..., nk , .....) where n1 , n2 , ..., nk , ... are distinct positive
integers.Note that we do not have zero as an entry in the sequences even though there are
any number of empty boxes because for the process to be described in the following these
empty boxes are irrelevant except when all of them are empty. We describe a process of
evaporation of particles from the boxes in the following way: at a time from each box a
single particle is evaporated.In other words, we define evaporation per unit time via the the
map (n1 , n2 , ..., nk , ...) → (n1 − 1, n2 − 1, ..., nk − 1, ...) (if n1 = 1, then there is no entry
at the location of n1 − 1). Note that this map is two-to-one.We arrive at the configuration
(n1 −1, n2 −1, ..., nk −1, ....) either from the evaporation of the configuration (n1 , n2 , ..., nk , ....)
or (1, n1 , n2 , ..., nk , ....).The dynamics of the evaporation can not be analysed any more unless
we introduce some kind of distance or metric on the set of all possible configuration of the
particles in the boxes.This will tell us how far or close particle configurations are from each
other.An adhoc mathematical definition would do the job. However, we shall try to be as
close as possible to a physical situation. It is natural to assume that two configurations with
similar number of particles in the boxes are closer to each other than those with different
number of particles.The more the dissimilar number of entries in the two configurations
the further they are.Another assumption we would like to make is that two configurations
differing from each other in very large entries are not too far from each other.This sounds a bit
3

 unatural.However, it is required mathematically.Note that the configuration ∅, corresponding
to "no particle" in any of the boxes also belongs to the set of all possble configurations.
Therefore, the distance of any configuration from the null configuration ∅ essentially defines
a norm.Now if the distance between two configurations keep increasing with larger entries
of particles in the boxes there will be problem with convergence of the norm.Therefore, the
two requirement mentioned above are necessary for defining a proper metric.This metric
introduces an interesting scenario for the evaporation process: there is a temporal scale
separation- the short time and long time behaviour of the evaporation is different in the
sense that two generic configurations which stay close to each other in short time separate
exponentially from each other in the long time.In fact, what will be proven in this paper is
that the set of possible configurations of particles in the boxes (i.e., the set of all subsets
of natural numbers Σ) is a Cantor set and the evaporation process (i.e.,the "Reduction by
Unity" map Ω on Σ) is chaotic.
A set is called a Cantor set if it is closed, totally disconnected and is a perfect set."Closed"
means every sequence of of its' points converges to some point within the set. "Totally diconnected" means it contains no interval.A perfect set means every point in it is an accumulation
point.The classical example of a Cantor set is the "Cantor middle-thirds" set.The "Cantor
middle-thirds" set is nicely described by Cantor map
F (x) = 3x for

− ∞ < x ≤ 1/2

= 3(1 − x) for

1/2 < x ≤ ∞

(8)

on the real line R.Note that most points of the real line R go to −∞ under the iteration of
the Cantor map.However, there exists a set which is a subset of the interval I=[0,1] that
does stay within the interval I and is invariant under the iteration of the map F(x).This is
precisely the "Cantor middle-thirds" set.The Cantor map F(x) on this set is chaotic [1,2].This
means that,
(1) The map has the property of sensitive dependence on initial conditions.
(2) It has dense set of periodic orbits.
4

 (3) It has a topologically transitive (chaotic) trajectory i.e., a trajectory which goes
arbitrary close to every point in the set.
We shall proof that the set of all subsets of natural numbers, Σ endowed with the metric
introduced in begining of paper, is homeomorphic to the Cantor set.In other words there
exists, between the "Cantor middle-thirds" set and the set of all subsets of natural numbers,
Σ, a mapping which is one-one , onto and continuous along with the the inverse.We shall
also proof that the Cantor map on Cantor set is topologically conjugate to the "Reduction
by Unity" map on Σ.
From the definition of the Cantor map, note that F ′ (x) = 3, and this means that the
map is expansive.Moreover, F −1 (I), where I = [0, 1],consists of two subintervals I0 = [0, 1/3]
and I1 = [2/3, 1].Also for any subinerval J ⊂ I, F −1 (J) consists of two subintervals, one
in I0 and the other in I1 .The length of the subinterval J is 3-times the length of either of
the subintervals F −1 (J). Also, F −n (I0 ) and F −n (I1 ) → 0 as 3−n . These properties of the
Cantor map can be used to establish a homeomorphism between Λ, the Cantor set and the
set Σ.
Let us construct the itinerary S(x) of a point x under the Cantor map F(x),
S(x) = (n1 , n2 , ..., nk , ....)

(9)

The symbols nj are introduced in the following way: nj ∈ S(x) if F nj −1 (x) ∈ I0 . It will
be argued that S(x) defined above is a homeomorphism.Firstly, it is obvious that to every
point x ∈ Λ, where Λ is the Cantor set, there is sequenc S(x) i.e., a subset of Σ.
Now we proof that to every subset of Σ there is a point x ∈ Λ. Let η = (1, 2, ..., n) and

exists a unique point x ∈ Λ, the Cantor set.This implies that the itinerary, S(x) is onto.
That distinct points of Cantor set, Λ correspond to different subsets of natural numbers
can be seen from the fact that the subintervals I n (x),containing the point x, ( constructed in

In order to proof continuity, let us choose an ǫ.Now choose n such that 1/2n < ǫ.Let
n
x ∈ Λ and S(x) = (n1 , n2 , ..., nk , ....).Consider all subintervals of the form Iξ,ζ
with n fixed

but ξ and ζ varying. There are 2n + 1 such intervals. These subintervals are disjoint and Λ
is contained in the union of them.Hence, we can choose a δ such that | x − y | < δ, and
y ∈ Λ, imply that y ∈ I n (x). Therefore, itinerary of the of the points , S(x) and S(y) agree
on n entries.Now, from the metric on Σ it follows that
k(S(x) − S(y))k ≤ 1/2n < ǫ

(14)

This proves continuity.Similarly, one can prove continuity of the inverse.Therefore, the
itinerary S(x) of points x ∈ Λ is a homeomorphism between the Cantor set, Λ and the
set of all subsets of natural number Σ.A set homeomorphic to a Cantor set is itself a Cantor
set. This proves the main claim of the paper.
Now, we describe some interesting and important corrolaries of this result. Now, we
prove that the "Reduction by Unity" map Ω on set Σ and Cantor map F(x) on set Λ are
topologically conjugate to each other.In other words,
S ◦ F (x) = Ω ◦ S(x)

A point x ∈ Λ is uniquely determined by intersection of nested sequence of intervals

The "Reduction by Unity" map Ω on the set of all subsets of natural numbers, Σ is topologically conjugate to the Cantor map F (x) on the Cantor set, Λ.This also proves that the
evaporation process introduced earlier is also chaotic.This hypothetical evaporation process
is a very generic example of chaos and, therefore, before we end the paper we mention the
following interesting corrollary.Let us construct a set of functions in the following way: to
every configuration α = (n1 , n2 , ..., nk , ....), we associate a function hα (x)
